facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1170 of 1968 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1170 of 1968. Appeal from the judgement and order dated February 3, 6, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Petition No. 104 of 1965. Mitra J. Ramamurthi, R. N. Sachthey and B. D. Sharma for the Appellant.

facts.text: Appeal arises from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated February 3, 6, 1967 in Misc. Petition No. 104 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgement and order dated February 3, 6, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Petition No. 104 of 1965. Mitra J. Ramamurthi, R. N. Sachthey and B. D. Sharma for the Appellant. C. Chagla, N.A. Palkhivala, Bhuvanesh Kumari, J. B. Dadachanji and Ravinder Narain for the respondent.

facts.text: Misc. Petition No. 104 of 1965 was filed in Bombay High Court under Article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: That was a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution. Therein the respondents challenged the validity of the orders of rectification made by the Income- tax Officer, Company Circle, Bombay in the assessments of the respondents for the assessment years 1958-59, 1960-61, 1961-62 and 1962-63 under S. 154 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.

facts.text: Respondents challenged validity of rectification orders by Income-tax Officer, Company Circle, Bombay for assessment years 1958-59, 1960-61, 1961-62, 1962-63 under S.154 of Income-tax Act, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Therein the respondents challenged the validity of the orders of rectification made by the Income- tax Officer, Company Circle, Bombay in the assessments of the respondents for the assessment years 1958-59, 1960-61, 1961-62 and 1962-63 under S. 154 of the Income-tax Act, 1961. Respondents Nos. 2 and 3 are the partners in the first respondent-firm.

facts.text: Respondents Nos. 2 and 3 are partners in the first respondent-firm.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents Nos. 2 and 3 are the partners in the first respondent-firm. The first respondent-firm was duly registered under the Indian Income-tax Act 1922 as well as under the Income-tax Act 1961.

facts.text: First respondent-firm was registered under Indian Income-tax Act 1922 and Income-tax Act 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent-firm was duly registered under the Indian Income-tax Act 1922 as well as under the Income-tax Act 1961. In the original assessments of the firm for the companycerned assessment years assessments were made on the salb rates prescribed under the respective Finance Acts applicable to registered Firms.

facts.text: Original assessments of the firm for assessment years 1958-59, 1960-61, 1961-62, 1962-63 made at slab rates for registered firms.

anchor.surface_text: In the original assessments of the firm for the companycerned assessment years assessments were made on the salb rates prescribed under the respective Finance Acts applicable to registered Firms. In the individual assessments of the partners for their respective share in the income of the firm was included and assessed at the maximum rates since their assessments were made in the status of number-resident.

facts.text: In individual assessments of partners, their share in firm income assessed at maximum rates as non-residents.

anchor.surface_text: In the individual assessments of the partners for their respective share in the income of the firm was included and assessed at the maximum rates since their assessments were made in the status of number-resident.

facts.text: On February 11, 1965, first respondent firm served with notices dated January 29, 1965 by Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On February, 11, 1965, the first respondent firm was served with numberices dated January 29, 1965 by the Income-tax Officer intimating to it that in its assessments for the assessment years 1958-59, 1960-61 , 1961-62 and 1962-63, there are mistakes apparent from the record

facts.text: Notices stated mistakes apparent in assessments for 1958-59 etc., firm not charged at maximum rates under S.17(1) of 1922 Act.

anchor.surface_text: intimating to it that in its assessments for the assessment years 1958-59, 1960-61 , 1961-62 and 1962-63, there are mistakes apparent from the record inasmuch as the firm had number been charged at the maximum rates of income-tax under S. 17 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: Respondents replied to notices denying any mistake apparent or otherwise and disputing ITO's authority to rectify.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in their reply to those numberices denied that there was any mistake apparent or otherwise in those orders of assessment. They disputed the Income-tax Officers authority to make any companyrection.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rectified assessments applying S.17(1) of 1922 Act despite objection.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer did number accept the companytention of the respondents and assessed them by applying the provisions of S. 17 i  of the 1922 Act. The respondents challenged the validity of the orders rectifying the assessments, before the High Court of Bombay as mentioned earlier.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held original assessments prima facie in accordance with law and no obvious mistake, so ITO incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the original assessments made on the respondents were prima facie in accordance with law and at any rate as there was numberobvious or patent mistake in those orders of assessment, the Income- tax Officer was incompetent to pass the impugned orders.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate from Bombay High Court decision in Misc. Petition No. 104 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate arises from the decision of the High Court of Bombay in Misc. Petition No. 104 of 1968 on its file. That was a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer purported to rectify under S.154 of Income-tax Act, 1961.
